title: Implement an OpenLibrary scans browser to identify table of contents pages, for later OCRing
description:
## Overview

Implement an OpenLibrary scans browser to identify table of contents pages, for later OCRing

## Success Criteria

- [ ] OpenLibrary book page images are browsable by users
- [ ] Users can mark any number of specific pages (recording the direct URLs of their images) as containing tables of contents
- [ ] Users can also check a box indicating "no explicit table of contents"
- [ ] Toc entities start as new. Once TOC pages have been marked OR "no explicit table of contents" has been marked and the form submitted, change their status to 'pages_marked'

## Background

Toc entities in status 'pages_marked' are ready for OCR or transcription of their tables of contents.

## Scope

**In Scope:**
- New toc view
- Edit toc view

**Out of Scope:**
- OCR process

description:
## Overview

We want users to be able to make TOCs for publications in Project Gutenberg as well. (Until now, only the Open Library was supported as a source.)

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Users can select a source to query before searching for publications. In addition to the Open Library, Project Gutenberg should be listed as an option now.
- [ ] Search Project Gutenberg using an instance of Gutendex. The constants.yml (example in constants.yml.example file) file should now contain variables pointing to the Gutendex public API URL.
- [ ] When a Project Gutenberg text is selected, create a ToC for it with status 'empty'. Support multi-selecting titles to make ToCs for, as with Open Library. Record the full-te
- [ ] When viewing a Toc based on a Project Gutenberg text, instead of browsing scans, offer to browse the fulltext content (defaulting to HTML, falling back to plaintext). The URLs are in the 'formats' key in the Book JSON returned by the Gutendex API. The fulltext view should open to the right of the TOC transcription textarea, and have limited height, with a vertical scrollbar.
- [ ] Mock the Gutendex API for tests

## Background

- the Gutendex API is described here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/garethbjohnson/gutendex/refs/heads/master/readme.md

## Scope

**Out of Scope:**
- setting up the Gutendex API server

description:
## Feature Request

When requesting a particular book's information from the Gutendex API, the results may include subject headings (in an array under the 'subjects' key). Import all such subject headings into a new text field on Toc, and during Toc editing, show imported subject heading strings alongside the publication subject headings of the Toc. Include a button named 'Attempt auto-match'. When clicked, run each subject heading (first gsub all ' -- ' into '--', to match Library of Congress norms) against the Library of Congress subject heading API to look for matches. Automatically add an aboutness for any EXACT match, and show an interface inviting the user to either accept or reject other matches, if no precise match is found. An accepted match should create an Aboutness linking to that LCSH. When an Aboutness is created, either automatically from an exact match or by user selection, the text subject heading that started the search should be removed from the text field, leaving only the other imported subject headings for later consideration.

All this is relevant only at the whole-Toc (publication) level, not the included manifestations.

## Motivation

This saves user time by importing subject headings already available in Project Gutenberg.

Design and implement a people-matcher UI element
description:
In several contexts we would need to associate an object (a Toc, a Work, an Expression) with a Person. This is often complex due to our input being strings (sometimes even not full names but initials) and our aim being to link to specific well-identified entities in external authority databses (VIAF, Wikidata, Library of Congress).

We need a UI component to perform such associations. I am not sure of the most appropriate UX -- a modal dialog? a collapsible? -- and would like you to consider and decide what would work best, based on the requirements.

Given a name string (mandatory) and optionally a set of one or more candidate identifications (in the form of [source,ID,name string], e.g. ['wikidata', 'Q42', 'Douglas Adams']), search our own database of Persons as well as all defined authority sources (VIAF, Wikidata, Library of Congress) for the given name string, and show the user the results in four parallel scrollable lists (one per source). Any candidate identifications given in advance (those would be drawn from the context of the containing publication or input by the user outside this UI element) should be placed at the TOP of the results from the specified source, with some emphasis or a "likely in context" badge, to help the user consider those potential matches first. Provide basic information about each return search result -- at the very least, life years and country, if known. Also, mark any result from an external source that is linked to one of our existing Person records with a badge like 'in DB', to signal to the user that this is a person already linked to some works or Tocs in our database.

Each potential match presented to the user should have a collapsible triggered by a button; if the user clicks the button, more context should be loaded from the relevant source about the person, to assist the user in determining whether that's the right match. The precise context should match what's available in the source, and loaded via AJAX on demand (not in advance).

Each result should also have a 'Match!' button. Once a user clicks that button, associate the object the UI element was launched with (Toc, Work, Expression) with the selected Person. If the match chosen is from one of the external sources that don't have a Person linked yet, create a new Person record and populate it with as much authority data as possible: for instance, if a Wikidata item was selected, create a Person recording that Wikidata QID, but also look up that Wikidata item and check whether it has a P244 property linking to the Library of Congress, and record that if it does, and likewise whether it has a VIAF ID (P214). Likewise when creating a person from VIAF or LoC.

This is complex, so after reading all this, first come up with a UX/UI design for such a component, mock it up, and show me one or several possibilities (with mock data), and name the one you would most recommend. After I give input, you can proceed to implement. Consider breaking implementation down into several beads.

title: Associate people with works Upon marking a TOC as transcribed
description:
Once a Toc is marked as transcribed, prepare a preview of matching the works it contains with people, according to the following logic:

0. All associations require manual user confirmation, using the shared/person_matcher modal.
1. For any work that has an explicit author listed (using || [author name] after the title, e.g. "# Hamlet || William Shakespeare"), try to match against that name.
2. For works without an explicit author listed, inherit the authors already associated with the parent level (another Manifestation, or the Toc level). Pass those as optional identities to the person_matcher.
3. By default, the role of the associated person is 'author'. However, if the name is surrounded in square brackets, make the role 'translator'. For example, an English edition of "The Name of the Rose" would be listed as "# The Name of the Rose || Umberto Eco; [William Weaver]"

description:
## Overview

Currently authors are stored as strings. (In imports from Open Library, the Open Library identifier is also stored.)

We want to enable users to map those strings to specific authority records in one of several sources: VIAF.org, Wikidata, or the Library of Congress Authority records.

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Users can initiate a query and (manual) selection view for EACH author name (some works will have more than one). Upon selecting a match, it will get recorded ALONGSIDE the existing string. Also record a *ROLE* for the person (by default: 'author', but we expect many 'translator' roles as well, at the very least) in the context of the specific publication or individual work. The association of this external ID should be made to the Person record, but the role should be recorded in a link table between the Publication/Work and the Person.
- [ ] Existing associations can be corrected (by deleting and associating anew)
- [ ] Also record Project Gutenberg author IDs (e.g. https://gutenberg.org/ebooks/author/4527 for Ernest Renan) on importing from Project Gutenberg

description: it currently crashes because it assume the author hash has OpenLibrary data. We need to support the Project Gutenberg case, and ideally prepare for future sources too. Better to create a standardized key and ensure we populate it from both Open Library and Project Gutenberg sources.
